p:
The MH-IV phase has an orthorhombic crystal cell based on an ice I h skeleton with the same stoichiometry as MH-III, i.e., a 2:1 D 2O:CH 4 ratio. This indicates that the MH-III
→
MH-IV transition can happen at constant chemical potential, without need of providing or removing atoms. The space group of MH-IV is Pmcn (n°62) where oxygen and carbon atoms occupy 4c Wyckoff sites ( Table 1). MH-IV contains ordered methane molecules and differs from MH-III where both ice network and methane ordering are concerned. The water network of MH-IV is much closer to ice I h than that of the MH-III phase, which is substantiated by a quantitative estimate of the topological distance (i.e., relying on the reduced coordinates) between the oxygen atoms of those 2 hydrate phases and ice I h. Indeed in MH-III there are 4-, 6-, and 8-fold water rings while in MH-IV the H-bonded water network is composed of corrugated ( a– b) sheets of edge-sharing 6-member rings of water molecules which are cross-linked along
c
→
as in ice I h, thus avoiding the angular frustration that 4-member water rings imply.
